name: Full-time employed college graduates, by sex, major occupation, age, ethnicity, race, disability status, and citizenship status: 2017
description: Full-time employed college graduates, by sex, major occupation, age, ethnicity, race, disability status, and citizenship status: 2017

creator.name: National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics

variableMeasured.name: field_not_hispanic_or_latino_american_indian_or_alaska_native
variableMeasured.description: Not Hispanic Or Latino American Indian Or Alaska Native

variableMeasured.name: field_not_hispanic_or_latino_black_or_african_american
variableMeasured.description: Not Hispanic Or Latino Black Or African American

variableMeasured.name: field_not_hispanic_or_latino_native_hawaiian_or_other_pacific_islander
variableMeasured.description: Not Hispanic Or Latino Native Hawaiian Or Other Pacific Islander

variableMeasured.name: field_not_hispanic_or_latino_more_than_one_race
variableMeasured.description: Not Hispanic Or Latino More Than One Race

specialValues.D: suppressed to avoid disclosure of confidential information

notes: Numbers are rounded to the nearest 1,000. Detail may not add to total because of rounding. Full-time employed college graduates are individuals working 35 or more hours per week on their principal job. Hispanic or Latino may be any race; race categories exclude Hispanic origin. The National Survey of College Graduates asks the degree of difficulty—none, slight, moderate, severe, or unable to do—an individual has in seeing (with glasses), hearing (with hearing aid), walking without assistance, lifting 10 pounds, or concentrating, remembering, or making decisions. Those respondents who answered "moderate," "severe," or "unable to do" for an activity were classified as having a disability.
sources: National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics, National Survey of College Graduates, 2017.
